channel.title: Buying a new computer
channel.description: Hello Moparscape, I don't really know anything about hardware and wanted to know where should I start on buying parts for a new PC? I heard A custom built PC for $500 can handle most games that don't demand that much. Can any help me? I don't know how to set anything up either but i'll figure it out :P

item.title: Buying a new computer
item.dc:creator: @nickog15 nickog15
item.description:
@nickog15 wrote:

Hello!
Building a computer can be complex and frustrating at times. I have not personally built my OWN computer, but we took one apart and reassembled it in my computer repair class. Check out these videos by new egg tv and you will learn how to build your own computer. It’s pretty lengthy though, about two hours. Don’t rush it though!
Part One - 24:33
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lPIXAtNGGCw

Part Two - 43:41
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d_56kyib-Ls

Part Three - 51:24
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RxaVBsXEiok

Goodluck!

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new computer
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

-Nothing:

I’ve built 3 PC’s and I’ve never used those faggy gloves or that wrist band shit. You people really make this bigger than it is, like chillwitm88 said, it’s like putting lego parts together.

Well I have killed my motherboard before, and I don’t like RMA’ing things and waiting a week and a half to get it back. If you don’t have any anti-static equipment, then you can just tap the metal on the power supply before touching anything important. Also, don’t set the processor on carpet or anything. Glass is acceptable.

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new computer
item.dc:creator: @SilentCJ SilentCJ
item.description:
@SilentCJ wrote:

-Nothing:

I’ve built 3 PC’s and I’ve never used those faggy gloves or that wrist band shit. You people really make this bigger than it is, like chillwitm88 said, it’s like putting lego parts together.

Mmm I dunno, I’d never bothered before but with my most recent build by the time it was all installed nothing would work, either the motherboard was defective on arrival or I’d managed to damage it, tried breadboarding and everything, but I RMA’d it and installed the new one using anti-static wristband and it was all good.

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new computer
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

[quote=“Fridder, post:13, topic:479227”][quote author=ziplock link=topic=597459.msg4210168#msg4210168 date=1359419649]
Less gay:

http://www.bhphotovideo.com/bnh/controller/home?O=&sku=405122&is=REG&Q=&A=details
[/quote]

Gloves are easier for me, sometimes you could clip that to the wrong metal or you don’t have a close enough metal to you (maybe you have a plastic case).

Using that wrist band compared to gloves is like using a phone with a cord attached to the wall versus a wireless phone.[/quote]

Another plus to the gloves is that while you’re repairing computers, you also have the ability of looking fabulous! I’ve actually never used gloves though. (I didn’t know they even existed) Does it make it harder to grip tiny things? Such as the tiny wires that connect the different case components to the motherbaord.

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new computer
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

chillwitm888:

its basically like putting lego together

You shouldn’t be comparing building a computer to putting Lego’s together.
Building a computer is more precise, you have to position the parts correctly, and make sure you put things in the rights spot. There is also a lot of precautions that need to be taken, and usually you have to be careful with the parts. Especially if you plan to put the processor in on your own. Plus if the motherboard, power supply, or something else isn’t installed correctly, or isn’t grounded, you can short out your motherboard/power supply, or other components.

As said earlier, just view tutorials on the internet, but take your precautions and handle the pieces of hardware with care.

Read full topic

item.title: Buying a new computer
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

crazyspecz:

When I get more money I can always add onto it? What’s better to add on? RAM, a new cpu? I always thought RAM was that thing that made your FPS high. I now know it’s not the only thing.

You want to buy a good CPU, because chances are if you buy a low grade CPU and you want to upgrade later, you will probably have to buy another motherboard also, and that’s a waste. So go ahead and put most of your money into the CPU. RAM is dirt cheap, but without a good processor and GPU, it will do nothing to increase gaming performance.

Read full topic

item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“chillwitm888, post:5, topic:479227”]just put shit in the case, building pc these days are dummy proofed
its basically like putting lego together, you just can’t screw it up unless
you have uncompatible mobos psus and/or not big enough case
here: i will include a 500$ build
without the OS: http://pcpartpicker.com/p/zcot
it accumulates to around 462$ there will be no hardware issues, if you do it right
with the OS (win 7 home premium) (Lower specs but does the job):
http://pcpartpicker.com/p/zcxb
491$
I think those are the best you can get for less than 500$[/quote]I shit bricks when I actually clicked those links. I had no idea all that stuff together was that cheap nowadays.
